title: How should one use 'In which'? Is it formal or informal? Are 'in which' and 'which in' interchangeable? - Quora

response.answer_text: ‘In which’ is fairly formal, yes, and most people never use it. In most cases we’ll either end the clause or sentence with ‘in’ or build the sentence differently. For example, I might write, “This is a government in which I have little confidence,” but I’d say either, “This is a government (that) I have little confidence in” or simply “I have little confidence in this government.” The same would apply to other prepositions with ‘which,’ e.g. ‘of which’ and ‘to which.’ Their chief function is to allow someone to avoid ending a sentence with a preposition, but sometimes these phrases are useful in long, complex sentences. And no, ‘in which’ and ‘which in’ are not interchangeable. ‘Which in’ would probably be found in a situation where the ‘in’ is simply part of a prepositional phrase following the relative pronoun ‘which,’ e.g. “I have a bad knee, which in some situations locks up and causes me to fall.”

In which is used to link a dependent clause to its independent clause, whenever “in" forms part of the predicate. (“Which in" is not used so, no, they're not interchangeable.) In which does sound more formal than its equivalent formation, as these two sentences show: This is something in which I believe. This is something I believe in. The first form is more likely to occur in writing; the second is the more common spoken form.
